Scenario.title: The Warmth Protocol
Scenario.situation: Front desk alert: A patient walks in. How do you respond?

option1.text: Smile politely, greet and ask ‘Hi, is this your first visit? If not, please give me your file.
option1.feedback:
Good start! Smile and greet, but 
don’t rush the file. Add warmth.

option2.text: “May I see your file?” Skip the smile, they’re in pain, it’s a hospital.
option2.feedback:
Oops! Fast is fine, but empathy 
matters. A smile heals.

option3.text: Smile, greet, and say, “Good morning, I’m Lee. How can I help you today?”
option3.feedback:
Well done! Smiling, greeting, 
and introducing yourself sets a positive 
tone and commitment to care.

option4.text: Smile, greet, and say, “Good morning, I’m Lee. Welcome to AIG Hospitals, happy to serve you. How can I help?”
option4.feedback:
Uh-huh! Smile and 
greet, but keep it professional. 
Patient needs comfort.

option5.text: Don’t interfere, they’ll call if they need help.
option5.feedback:
Alas! Don’t wait, a
ct! Anticipate, help, and
 show kindness.

Scenario.title: The Warmth Protocol
Scenario.situation: A distressed family with a patient in wheelchair approaches the ER

option1.text: Smile and Greet: “I'm Su. How can I help today?”
option1.feedback:
Polite, yes, but 
patients need urgency and 
warmth.

option2.text: Skip the smile, alert the doctor now.
option2.feedback:
Hold up! Understand 
first, then act.

option3.text: Approach fast: “I'm Su. here to assist. What's the issue.”
option3.feedback:
Bravo! Fast, clear, and 
caring, just right 
for the ER.

option4.text: Yell out, “How did this happen? Who's responsible?”
option4.feedback:
Not right! Shouting creates 
fear. Stay composed and 
helpfull.

option5.text: Smile Politely and ask gently, “What is your concern”
option5.feedback:
Too much! Patients 
want calm assurance, 
not overacting.

Scenario.title: The Warmth Protocol
Scenario.intro: An attender approaches you with a kid in tow and says
Scenario.dialogue:
My daughter is in pain for 8 months.
 Medicines failed. Need urgent
 appointment, only 2 days in hand
 before I neeed to travel back to be 
with wife and younger son!
Scenario.situation: Daughter in pain for 8 months, meds useless. needs urgent appointment, 2-day deadline.

option1.text: Smile and say, “Help Desk will take care of you.”
option1.feedback:
Too passive! Show the path clearly, 
don't leave them guessing.

option2.text: Lead him to the Help Desk, see if your other colleagues has time for tea.
option2.feedback:
Tea break can wait! 
Focus on the patient.

option3.text: Cut to the chase: “Please give the patient's name and phone number to start registration.” No need to smile, he is in a hurry.
option3.feedback:
Quick work, yes, but k
indness counts.

option4.text: Smile and say: “Good afternoon, I'm Mel. Let's complete registration, then apointment. Head of Help Desk on the ground floor. Don't worry, your daughter will be taken care of.”
option4.feedback:
Excellent! kindness, clear, 
and comforting, perfect service!.

option5.text: Smile politely and ask gently “What is your concern?”
option5.feedback:
Correct rules, wrong tone! 
Be gently and guiding.
